name: Rufous Hornbill
description: Hornbills are striking, robust birds with a large beak topped by a casque. Though it may appear massive, this structure is very light, mostly filled with air, covered by a thin layer of keratin, and reinforced internally by a network of fine bony struts. The rufous hornbill has a rusty neck and underbelly, gray wings, a white tail, a black mask, and a red beak. Chicks are initially black and white.
image_alt: Rufous hornbill, photo: Antonín Vaidl, Prague Zoo
proportions: Length 60–65 cm including tail; female weight 1.1–1.6 kg, male weight 1.3–1.8 kg
attractions: Like all hornbills, it lives in permanent pairs. During nesting, the female retreats into a tree hollow, which the male seals, leaving only a small opening to bring her food. After the chicks hatch, the female leaves the hollow after a time, and both parents then feed the young until they fledge, often assisted by older offspring. Its main food is figs, but it also eats insects, catching them even in flight.
breeding: We have kept rufous hornbills since 2011.
